# File Structure

**Project Organization:**

```
your-project/
├── presentation.Rmd          # This file
├── styles/
│   └── custom.css            # Styling
├── assets/
│   └── images/               # Your logos
```

**Note:** The `python_env/` folder is auto-created on first knit (2-3 min).

---

# Quick Start

**Step 1:** Edit YAML Header

```yaml
title: "Your Presentation Title"
author: "Your Name"
```

**Step 2:** Edit the `layout: true` section to change header/footer

**Step 3:** Use `---` to create new slides!

**Inline:** $E = mc^2$ appears within text.

$$\mathbb{E}(X) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i \cdot p(x_i)$$
]

.pull-right[

$$\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}$$
]

# R Visualization

.pull-left[
```{r r-plot, eval=FALSE}
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, 
                   color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Weight vs MPG",
       x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
       y = "MPG", color = "Cyl") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
```
]

# Python Visualization

.pull-left[
```{python py-plot, eval=FALSE}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y1, y2 = np.sin(x), np.cos(x)

plt.figure(figsize=(5, 4))
plt.plot(x, y1, label='sin(x)', lw=2)
plt.plot(x, y2, label='cos(x)', lw=2)
plt.xlabel('X'); plt.ylabel('Y')
plt.title('Sine and Cosine')
plt.legend(); plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
plt.tight_layout(); plt.show()
```

# Python Scatter Plot

.pull-left[
```{python py-scatter, eval=FALSE}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

np.random.seed(42)
n = 100
x = np.random.randn(n)
y = 2 * x + np.random.randn(n)
colors = np.random.rand(n)

plt.figure(figsize=(5, 4))
plt.scatter(x, y, c=colors, s=50, 
            alpha=0.6, cmap='viridis')
plt.colorbar(label='Value')
plt.xlabel('X'); plt.ylabel('Y')
plt.title('Scatter Plot')
plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
plt.tight_layout(); plt.show()
```
]

# Interactive Clustering

```{r cluster, echo=FALSE, fig.height=4, fig.width=9}
set.seed(42)
d <- rbind(
  data.frame(x = rnorm(50, 2, 0.8), y = rnorm(50, 2, 0.8)),
  data.frame(x = rnorm(50, 6, 1), y = rnorm(50, 6, 1)),
  data.frame(x = rnorm(50, 2, 0.9), y = rnorm(50, 7, 0.9))
)
km <- kmeans(d, 3, nstart = 20)
d$cluster <- as.factor(km$cluster)

p <- ggplot(d, aes(x, y, color = cluster)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#E63946", "#457B9D", "#2A9D8F")) +
  labs(title = "K-Means Clustering (hover to explore)", x = "X", y = "Y") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12)

ggplotly(p, height = 380) %>% layout(margin = list(t = 40))
```

---

# Projectile Motion

.pull-left[
**Equations of Motion:**

$$x(t) = v_0 \cos(\theta) \cdot t$$

$$y(t) = v_0 \sin(\theta) \cdot t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2$$

**Range:** $R = \frac{v_0^2 \sin(2\theta)}{g}$
]

.pull-right[
```{r projectile, echo=FALSE, fig.height=4, fig.width=5.5}
g <- 9.81; v0 <- 20
df <- data.frame()
for (th in c(30, 45, 60)) {
  rad <- th * pi / 180
  t <- seq(0, 2*v0*sin(rad)/g, length.out = 100)
  df <- rbind(df, data.frame(x = v0*cos(rad)*t, 
    y = v0*sin(rad)*t - 0.5*g*t^2, angle = paste0(th, "°")))
}
ggplot(df, aes(x, y, color = angle)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) + scale_color_viridis_d() +
  labs(title = "Trajectories (v₀=20m/s)", x = "Distance (m)", y = "Height (m)") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 11) + coord_fixed()
```
]

---

# Simple Harmonic Motion

.pull-left[
**Equation:**

$$x(t) = A\cos(\omega t + \phi)$$

**Angular Frequency:**

$$\omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$$

**Energy:** $E = \frac{1}{2}kA^2$
]

.pull-right[
```{r shm, echo=FALSE, fig.height=3.5, fig.width=5.5}
t <- seq(0, 4*pi, length.out = 200)
df <- data.frame(t = rep(t, 2),
  y = c(cos(t), -sin(t)),
  type = rep(c("Position", "Velocity"), each = 200))

p <- ggplot(df, aes(t, y, color = type)) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#E63946", "#457B9D")) +
  labs(x = "Time", y = "Amplitude", color = "") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) + theme(legend.position = "bottom")
ggplotly(p, height = 320)
```
]

# Tips

1. **Keep slides simple** - One idea per slide
2. **Use visuals** - Charts over tables
3. **Interactive plots** - Use `ggplotly(p, height = 380)`
4. **Test math** - No blank lines around `$$`
